update.description:
First draft of the rendering system. It's still a work in progress, I'm opening the PR for visibility and to get feedback from @iche033.

---

## Functionality

* Initialize render engine and scene on constructor
* On update, create a `rendering::Visual` for every entity that has a pose and a parent. 
    * This includes "invisible" visuals like models and links, so we can set their poses and affect eventual visible children.
    * If there's no visual for the parent, we assume the parent is the world and attach it to the scene root
* Create geometry and material from SDF objects
* At subsequent updates, update visual pose

---

## Issues

The scene is being initialized properly, because we can see the background color is the one we chose.

But no visuals are showing up. Neither the box created on the constructor nor the shapes created on the update callback. I suspect the render window is never being repainted. @iche033, do you think this is indeed the problem, or is there something wrong in the code?

---

## Usage

Load `shapes.world` as follows:

    ign-gazebo -v 4 -f ../test/worlds/shapes.sdf
update.title: [WIP] Rendering system
update.reason: holding off on a rendering system for now

content.raw:
Issues:

* All Ogre 1.9 calls must be made from the same thread
* Moreover, all ign-rendering calls must be made from the Qt thread
* So we'd need the rendering system to be aware of all this

This will likely be fixed / improved when we move to Ogre 2.1 - we will revisit this PR then.

For now, there will be a `ScenePublisher` system publishing scene messages to be consumed by an ign-gui plugin which extends `ignition::gui::plugins::Scene3D`. See pull request #41 for the first PR.

content.raw:
The intention was that the rendering system would create and update the scene, while all the `Scene3D` plugin would do is paint the a camera view onto a window.

So just to be sure, absolutely all ign-rendering API must always be called from the same thread? Does that include both "read" (getting current camera image) and "write" (creating/modifying scene) operations? If this is something we only need to do for the GUI, then is it ok to use various threads for the sensor's scene?

content.raw:
mm how does the Render system work with the Scene3D plugin? 

In Scene3D, there’s [logic for managing the opengl context](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/src/df7598268ad4f3d7c27bf45dc4cf3617c193da1b/src/plugins/Scene3D.cc#lines-215). The render window context needs to be activated before any ign-rendering calls and deactivated afterwards so it does not interfere with Qt. We also need to make sure all the ign-rendering calls happen in the same thread. 

It’s kind of inconvenient but it seems like it’s the way to go for getting ogre to work with QtQuick
content.html:
mm how does the Render system work with the Scene3D plugin?

In Scene3D, there’s logic for managing the opengl context. The render window context needs to be activated before any ign-rendering calls and deactivated afterwards so it does not interfere with Qt. We also need to make sure all the ign-rendering calls happen in the same thread.

It’s kind of inconvenient but it seems like it’s the way to go for getting ogre to work with QtQuick
